doc.title: Global Macro Strategy - Views and Trade Ideas
doc.source_uri: 2025-08-29/Global Macro Strategy - Views and Trade Ideas NVDA and ChileGlobal Macro Strategy - Views and Trade Ideas NVDA and Chile_2025-08-29

passages.text: The NVDA quarter suggests that the US Al boom continues. We remain overweight US equities but had tactically taken profits in our TWSE long ahead of the print. We would add additional equity risk on a seasonal September pull- back. We add USDCLP topside to our radar heading into the Latam election season. We reiterate our paid 1yly in Japan, in line with BoJ Governor Ueda's Jackson Hole speech. We recently added to both steepeners and USD shorts given rising risks of a more dovish FOMC in case of a Lisa Cook exit. We think continued political risks in France will not impact EUR much but can more easily be positioned for in the equity space.

US Al boom on track, though September is close - - NVDA earnings have not been a trigger either way. We remain big believers in the US capex and Al boom, and stay invested. However, we tactically took profits on our TWSE long and wait for a seasonal September pullback to add additional risk.

Latam election season is starting - - Chile is starting the Latam election season. With the first round due on Nov \(16^{\mathrm{th}}\) , the market is entering the window when the election trade typically works. We add USDCLP topside to our radar.

Ueda does Jackson - - BoJ Governor Kazuo Ueda's speech in Jackson Hole suggests that the hiking cycle in Japan remains on track thanks to a tight labor market. We remain paid 1yly, but also receiving the Oct meeting, as continued uncertainty makes an October hike less likely.

If Cook exits, it could start a meaningful FOMC shift - - While the end of Fed Chair Jerome Powell's term is fast approaching, the "one- man risk" of losing him as Chair may not be the Fed's biggest risk to the FOMC configuration. If the latest development on Governor Cook ends up in her exit, it would mean that the Board of Governors could soon have a dovish majority (4/7). Risk of a significantly more dovish FOMC has two main market release valves, in our view: weaker USD and steeper curve. We are already in 5s30s steepeners and short USD. We added a small new position to both themes.

France: No budget; no government, no problem? - - USD weakness has been contained, partly because coincident French fiscal concerns have dominated headlines. However, our event study shows that the recent widening of OAT- Bund spreads is unlikely to materially undermine the appetite for the Euro going forward. The negative political risk premia trade is likely better expressed in relative equities (CAC40 underperforming) than in EURUSD lower or chasing the OAT- Bund move, in our view.

NVDA earnings in line with continued AI boom. The NVDA earnings release has been the key macro event of the week. Ahead of time we had trimmed risk by taking profits on our Taiwan equity long (see Global Macro Strategy: Fed trumps French politics - add to US 5s30s steepeners, USD shorts). The reason was not so much fear of a NVDA miss, but a sense that the risk reward into the number was not clear cut at a time when September has famously poor seasonals for equities, and as we expect the continued TGA build to impact liquidity negatively. In the event, NVDA has not been a negative catalyst. While the stock is slightly weaker, our equity analyst thinks that the quarter was largely in line, as was guidance. The guidance does not include China business, as NVDA has not shipped to China in the just reported quarter. Maybe more importantly for macro investors, NVDA expects a 3 to 4 trn USD AI infrastructure spend by the end of 2030, suggesting that a multi- year AI capex boom is not slowing down any time soon.

NVDA not a macro event, but we still wait for an equity pull- back to add additional risk to our equity longs. Overall, the NVDA quarter was not a trigger for widespread profit taking, as the story remains well on track. We have been big AI and tech bulls for some time and have been trading US equities and US tech from the long side again since early April. However, we also have pointed out that September can be seasonally tricky and that liquidity is likely to tighten in September with the TGA rebuild, another negative factor. Given these two factors we continue to wait for a pull- back to add additional risk to our existing equity longs. As suggested last week, China is a candidate to add risk, but China also suffers from very poor September seasonals. We therefore bid our time.
Earlier this week we discussed the potential for rising dovishness by the FOMC, and have added to both our steepener as well as our EUR shorts. We expand on our earlier arguments below.

Latam election season heating up. Chile will open the presidential election season in Latam on November 16th, with Colombia and Brazil following later. Our rule of thumb is that markets start to care around 3 months before, making now a good time to start to pay attention.

Chile presidential election with a wide range of candidates. The candidates, ordered by polling market expectations (Figure 1), are right candidate Jose Antonio Kast, left candidate Jeannette Jara, center- right candidate Evelyn Matthei, and populist candidate Franco Parisi. Kast's popularity has surged with a focus on law and order. He has labeled his economic plan "The Takeoff" (El Despegue), emphasizing deregulation, VAT tax cuts, and trimming public spending. His pro- business stance, including additional support for free trade and investment, will likely be welcomed by markets. Jara has proposed more state- led growth (social programs), higher taxes, and public ownership of lithium, which would be seen as a negative by markets. Matthei is campaigning on aggressive spending cuts and a gradual reduction in corporate taxes. Seen as fiscally responsible, moderate, Matthei presidency could excite markets. Not much is known about Parisi's positions yet, but we would expect some caution.

Figure 2. USDCLP tends to peak between the first and second round

Uptick in Jara support needed for election trade. Typical election playbook is for the FX selloff into the first round and rally after the second round, which we saw in the last three Chilean elections (Figure 2). But this usually requires a tight election with two quite polarizing candidates who moderate once in office. Recent polling (Cadem, 8/24) suggests that Kast is the current favorite in presidential expectation with some margin, although in first round voting, Kast and Jara are effectively tied. Second- round match ups (Figure 4) show Kast winning against Jara and Matthei and Matthei beating Jara – both of which are not overly compelling for the election trade, in our view. However, with more than 2 months to go, there is still much that can change. Momentum may shift from Kast to another candidate. Jara could soften her left image and commit to more fiscal discipline, which could narrow margins. If Jara were to narrow the gap, markets would likely react by selling Chile assets.

Alternatively, broader USD strength would help. In our experience it is often the case that investors are quite forgiving with a country's fundamentals, when the USD is on a backfoot. On the other hand, if the USD were to strengthen, investors would look for USD longs more aggressively, focusing on weaker stories like CLP. While a stronger USD is not our base case, we believe this would also help the election trade to come into its own.
Figure 3. Kast leading in presidential expectations, but first round polling is essentially a tie between Kast and Jara
Figure 4. In potential second round match-ups, Kast wins over other candidates

FX intervention also supporting higher USDCLP. On August \(5^{\text{th}}\) , the central bank announced that it was going to be buying 25mn USD every day to shore up reserves. The FX accumulation is expected to run for 3 years and to increase reserves from \(13.8\%\) to \(18\%\) of GDP by 2028. While \(\) 25\mathrm{mn}$ per day is quite small relative to previous interventions, the structural selling of CLP should be a headwind to any CLP rallies. In the 2008 and 2011 USD buying intervention (Figure 5), CLP sold off immediately after the announcement, which we have not seen yet in the current episode. In 2008, USDCLP continued upward, while in 2011, USDCLP then slowly moved downward. So far, CLP has been rangebound, partially driven by sideways moves in the dollar. On the other side of the ledger, USDCLP has generally moved lower when the central bank started to sell USD, resulting overall in a decent track record for FX intervention overall.

Weaker copper outlook and a dovish BCCH are tailwinds as well. Our commodity team has been bearish on copper for some time and the BCCH has been in an easing cycle. Markets are pricing in 25bps of cuts for the next 3 meetings, but the BCCH is expected to stay dovish, with a neutral range of 3.5- 4.5, though we do expect a dovish Fed, too. Our backtest shows that weaker copper prices, falling terms of trade, and a tighter interest rate differential outperform the unconditional USDCLP. So far, neither the rates nor the CTOT signal has triggered, but a weaker copper market in line with Citi commodity strategy would certainly be helpful. Positioning is relatively neutral. Large inflows from leveraged accounts early this year were fully unwound in July but are not overly negative at this stage. Our EM strategists are also underweight CLP. We add USDCLP topside to our radar.
Figure 5. FX intervention usually results in an immediate move higher in USDCLP after the announcement that we haven't seen yet
Figure 6. Weak copper prices and dovish BCCh support higher USDCLP but the rates signal hasn't triggered yet

BoJ Governor Ueda speaks on policy implications of labor market transition (BoJ, Aug- 23- 25). Governor Ueda's speech at Jackson Hole touched upon the theme of a demographic decline in Japan (Figure 7) and its impact on the labour market, a theme we had previously covered in Consumer prices move first, growth fundamentals come second (05- Jun- 25). Pre- Covid inflation remained subdued despite some labour market tightness (Figure 8). Part of that story is that the spillover in full- time wages has been limited in the past, because of the steep increase in part- time workers among the elderly and female working population that partially compensated the labour market tightness (Figure 9). That said, as Governor Ueda reports, the scope for further increases is limited. The labour force participation rate for people aged 65 and over was above 25% in 2024, while the current female labour force participation rate is comparable to Northern European economies. With monetary policy still very loose, it's clear the labor market has not eased yet in Japan partially because the BoJ is yet to normalize policy, as shown in Figure 10. As Governor Ueda puts it, "Barring a major negative demand shock, the labor market is expected to remain tight and continue to exert upward pressure on wages." This dynamic also helps explain the 34- year high in this year's annual wage negotiation, and the pick- up in labour market mobility relative to historical highs (Figure 10).
Figure 7. A recent BoJ paper looked extensively at the implication of a shrinking working age population on the labour market

Question is when to resume cycle. Given the structural economic issues Japan currently faces, combined with a relatively benign US tariff negotiation outcome, the question is when will the BoJ resume its monetary policy normalization cycle. We got back in our JyPJ paid position in Views and Trade Ideas - Modest Oil Spike Unlikely to Derail Goldilocks (13- Jun- 2025). The trade is in line with our rates strategist view of underpriced BoJ and our economists' base case of a Jan 2026

first hike. Given election risks, which could leave the BoJ in a wait-and-see mode until both the economic outlook and political backdrop clear, we added a near-term hedge by receiving the October meeting. While election risks have diminished, they are not gone. NHK (25-Aug-2025) reported that the LDP is in the process to publish a summary document covering the Upper House election, which could be followed by a decision on leadership. Our economists' base case remains for the next hike to come in the Jan 2026 meeting. Along with the BoJ, we remain in wait and see mode, and maintain both our paid 1yly JPY position, as well as our Oct BoJ receiver, until we get a clearer picture on the election front.

We already like 5s30s, which should continue to do well on a dovish Fed pivot. We have been in 5s30s steepeners since May, for a mix of weaker hard data leading the front end lower, and ongoing issuance meaning the back end underperforms. We still think this mix of factors is likely to continue driving the curve steeper, especially with Chair Powell's focus on downside risks to the labour market at his Jackson Hole speech. Citi rates strategy also outlines why 5s30s is a good all- weather steeper for a cutting cycle - the right mix of low carry and expected move. For more, see US Rates Weekly - The curve can keep steepening. In Figure 11 they show that SOFR options on M6 and Z6 are pricing reasonable chance of sub- 3% SOFR in recent weeks. Figure 12 shows the 5s30s has similar risk adjusted moves and hit rates to 2s10s in a 2y rally, but has a better carry profile.

Risk of a larger FOMC would also weaken USD. Larger shifts in FOMC membership have been top of mind for markets since the beginning of President Trump's recurrent critiques of Fed Chair Powell's monetary policy (NYT, 16- Jul- 25). Yet, the "one- man risk" of losing Powell as Chair may not be the Fed's biggest risk to the FOMC configuration. As flagged in a recent WSJ article (24- Aug- 25), the term of the presidents of the 12 Regional Federal Reserve Banks, which runs concurrently, are all set to end in February 2026. Once their terms are over, the 12 regional Fed chairs must be reappointed by the Board of Governors. The Board of Governors currently already has two President Trump appointees (Governors Waller and Bowman), while Stephen Miran is incoming. If the latest development on Governor Cook ends up in her exit, it could mean that the Board of Governors would soon have a dovish majority (4/7) (latest developments shown in Figure 13).

In turn, with the term of the 12 District Banks heads coming to an end and dependent on the Board of Governors' approval, it could point to increased risks of a dovish FOMC. While this is more a risk scenario for the market rather than the base case, the WSJ article reports that in 2022 both Governor Bowman and Waller abstained from voting to approve the appointment of Goolsbee, a former economic adviser to President Obama, as president of the Chicago Fed. Risk of a more dovish FOMC has two main market release valves, in our view: weaker USD and steeper curve. We are already both short USD (EURUSD topside digi with window KO, USDTRY digi put, long carry basket, AUDUSD up, oil down dual digi) and long the 6m 5s30s steepener (in 6m fwd 5s30s and in a 5s30s steeper, NDX higher dual digital; trade idea owned by Adam Pickett), and we added a small position to both themes earlier this week.

Who chooses the new regional Federal Reserve Bank chairs, if the current ones are not confirmed? The District Banks are comprised of three class of directors: A, B and C. The search committee for the new District Bank's president is composed of Class B and Class C directors. The common denominator between all Class Directors is that they must serve the public's interest, but they are chosen by different entities. Class B directors are chosen by private banks, but they cannot be bank employees. Class C directors are chosen directly by the Board of Governors. The search committee then interviews a range of potential candidates and forwards to the Board of Governors a list of finalist candidates, all of whom are interviewed by the governors. Then the District Bank's Class B and C directors formally appoint a candidate, subject to the approval of the Board of Governors. It is unclear to us if a simple majority is needed.

Who replaces a regional Federal Reserve Bank chair in their absence? The alternate voters are linked voters in 4 consistent groupings as outlined on the Fed website: 1) Boston, Philadelphia, and Richmond; 2) Cleveland and Chicago; 3) Atlanta, St. Louis, and Dallas; and 4) Minneapolis, Kansas City, and San Francisco. As such, the 2026 alternate voters are listed in our table and on the Fed website in corresponding matching order to the voter they hypothetically would replace.

No budget, no government, no problem? The USD has been relatively stable despite a potentially more dovish Fed. Gold has also only moved up slightly (though is close to the highs). One reason is the coincident news flow around France. First, we note that fiscal fears in France are nothing new, OATs have been underperforming all year (Figure 16) with consistently weak portfolio flows in recent years (Figure 17). We see similar stretched weakness from Rates Strategy's risk premia models (Figure 18). Market participants have been expecting further OAT underperformance (slowly) and legislative elections (next year). We think the no confidence vote, which is likely to fail (per Citi Economics), simply front loads this price action. We think there is limited evidence that the recent spread widening in OAT- Bund spreads could materially undermine appetite for the Euro. In Figure 20, we ran an event study looking at EURUSD performance during periods when OAT- Bund spreads are stretched. To identify these periods, we apply two conditions which mirror the recent price action in OAT- Bund spreads: 1) the 1y rolling z- score of weekly changes exceeds 2 sigma and 2) the absolute weekly change is at least \(+10\) bps. The latter condition ensures we do not unintentionally capture periods of very low volatility that are not analogous to the current environment. Finally, we exclude overlapping events within a six- month window.

We are fading EURUSD weakness. We conclude that even after historical episodes of sharp spread widening, subsequent EURUSD performance has tended to track closely its unconditional path (black dashed line). Moreover, any EUR weakness tends to precede the spread blowout, suggesting that by the time stress becomes visible much of the adjustment has already been priced in (Figure 20). We therefore would be willing to fade the French news when it comes to FX, in line with FX Strategy. We would be wrong if there was a reasonably large likelihood of a resignation of President Macron, which our economists do not expect.

Relative weakness in French equities is the better expression. If investors want to position for more stress from France, a more targeted approach may be more compelling: with the same methodology we find that French equities keep underperforming for longer. This is more attractive, in our view, as the French narrative is somewhat unlikely to improve substantially going into the no confidence vote. We find limited OAT- Bunds follow through in our event studies, so wouldn't chase the rates move. Our equity strategists have also made a case for underperformance of French equities (see European Multi- Asset: French Political Risks on the Rise Again).

RISKS: When buying calls and puts (or receivers and payers) the maximum loss is the premium paid. When selling calls (or receivers), the maximum potential loss would occur as the index spread decreases but is limited by the index spread being floored at zero. For puts (or payers), the maximum potential loss (amount below the strike) would eventuate should the index price fall to zero. Sector index options are cash settled. Credit index options are physically settled. The above calculations do not include any additional fees or transaction costs. Note that ratio writing would leave the writer uncovered in one leg of the trade.
